Week 10: Final Presentations & Course Wrap-up

Overview

Our final week! Students will present their completed final projects and weâ€™ll reflect on the course journey. Weâ€™ll also discuss next steps for continuing your data visualization learning and practice.

Learning Objectives

By the end of this week, you will be able to:

  • Present a comprehensive data visualization project professionally
  • Evaluate and provide feedback on complex visualization work
  • Reflect on your growth throughout the course
  • Identify areas for continued learning and improvement
  • Plan your next steps in data visualization

Final Presentation Format

ðŸŽ¯ 8-minute presentations followed by 3-minute Q&A

Structure your presentation: 1. Problem and context (1 minute) 2. Data and methodology (1.5 minutes) 3. Design process and iterations (2 minutes) 4. Live demonstration (2 minutes) 5. Key insights and impact (1 minute) 6. Reflection and future work (30 seconds)

Presentation Schedule

Tuesday: Progress Check & Prep

  • Morning: Individual progress check-ins
  • Afternoon: Presentation practice sessions
  • Evening: Final project submission deadline

Thursday: Final Presentations

  • Session 1: Projects 1-8 (90 minutes)
  • Break: 30 minutes with refreshments
  • Session 2: Projects 9-16 (90 minutes)
  • Wrap-up: Course reflection and celebration

Evaluation Rubric

Technical Excellence (35%)

  • Sophisticated Implementation: Advanced techniques used appropriately
  • Code Quality: Clean, documented, reproducible
  • Data Handling: Proper preprocessing and validation
  • Performance: Efficient and responsive

Design & User Experience (35%)

  • Visual Design: Effective use of design principles
  • Accessibility: WCAG compliance and inclusive design
  • Usability: Intuitive interaction and navigation
  • Innovation: Creative solutions to visualization challenges

Communication & Impact (20%)

  • Storytelling: Clear narrative and compelling insights
  • Presentation: Professional delivery and demonstration
  • Documentation: Comprehensive project documentation
  • Audience Engagement: Effective Q&A and discussion

Process & Reflection (10%)

  • Iteration: Evidence of design evolution
  • Problem-solving: Handling of technical challenges
  • Learning: Demonstration of skill development
  • Critical Thinking: Thoughtful evaluation of choices

Course Reflection

Individual Reflection (Due with Final Project)

Write a 500-word reflection addressing: - What visualization skills have you developed? - Which projects or techniques were most challenging? - How has your understanding of design principles evolved? - What visualization work are you most proud of? - What areas do you want to continue developing?

Group Discussion Topics

  • Most valuable techniques learned
  • Biggest challenges overcome
  • Favorite projects from the course
  • Advice for future students
  • Industry trends and opportunities

Next Steps in Data Visualization

Continued Learning

  • Advanced Courses: Machine learning visualization, scientific visualization
  • Conferences: IEEE VIS, EuroVis, Information+
  • Online Communities: Data Visualization Society, r/dataviz
  • Books: Advanced texts and specialized topics

Portfolio Development

  • GitHub Pages: Showcase your projects
  • Observable: Interactive portfolio pieces
  • LinkedIn: Professional visualization content
  • Personal Website: Comprehensive portfolio

Career Paths

  • Data Analyst/Scientist: Visualization for analysis
  • UX/UI Designer: Information design and interfaces
  • Data Journalist: Storytelling with data
  • Business Intelligence: Dashboard and reporting design
  • Research Visualization: Academic and scientific visualization

Resources for Continued Growth

Communities

  • Data Visualization Society
  • Information is Beautiful
  • Flowing Data

Tools to Explore

  • Emerging Platforms: Observable, Figma, Framer
  • Specialized Tools: Tableau, Power BI, Qlik
  • Programming Libraries: D3.js, Three.js, Vega-Lite

Datasets for Practice

  • Kaggle Datasets
  • Data.gov
  • Our World in Data
Pro Tip

Keep creating! The best way to maintain and grow your visualization skills is through regular practice and experimentation.

Final Deadlines
  • Final Projects: Thursday, 11:59 PM
  • Reflection Essays: Thursday, 11:59 PM
  • Peer Evaluation Forms: Friday, 11:59 PM
Thank You!

Congratulations on completing SMM635 Data Visualization! Itâ€™s been a pleasure learning and creating with you. Keep visualizing!
